message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Argumentation and explainable artificial intelligence: a survey
Paper Abstract: Abstract Argumentation and eXplainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) are closely related, as in the recent years, Argumentation has been used for providing Explainability to AI. Argumentation can show step by step how an AI System reaches a decision; it can provide reasoning over uncertainty and can find solutions when conflicting information is faced. In this survey, we elaborate over the topics of Argumentation and XAI combined, by reviewing all the important methods and studies, as well as implementations that use Argumentation to provide Explainability in AI. More specifically, we show how Argumentation can enable Explainability for solving various types of problems in decision-making, justification of an opinion, and dialogues. Subsequently, we elaborate on how Argumentation can help in constructing explainable systems in various applications domains, such as in Medical Informatics, Law, the Semantic Web, Security, Robotics, and some general purpose systems. Finally, we present approaches that combine Machine Learning and Argumentation Theory, toward more interpretable predictive models.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "Machine Learning":

## Definition and Overview

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## Main Learning Paradigms

Machine learning is commonly separated into three main learning paradigms: supervised learning, unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning.

## Applications

ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine.

## Deep Learning and Neural Networks

Within a subdiscipline in machine learning, advances in the field of deep learning have allowed neural networks, a class of statistical algorithms, to surpass many previous machine learning approaches in performance.(no content)A neural network or neural net (NN), also called artificial neural network (ANN), is a computational model inspired by the structure and functions of biological neural networks.

## History

The term machine learning was coined in 1959 by Arthur Samuel, an IBM employee and pioneer in the field of computer gaming and artificial intelligence.(no content)By 2016 AlphaGo obtained victory against top human players using reinforcement learning techniques.

The search results provide comprehensive information on machine learning fundamentals, applications, and historical development.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Medical Informatics"

Links: [{"title":"Health informatics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_informatics"},{"title":"American Medical Informatics Association - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Medical_Informatics_Association"},{"title":"Health administration informatics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_administration_informatics"},{"title":"American College of Medical Informatics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_College_of_Medical_Informatics"},{"title":"Mental health informatics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mental_health_informatics"},{"title":"Health Informatics Society of Australia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_Informatics_Society_of_Australia"},{"title":"Brazilian Society of Health Informatics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brazilian_Society_of_Health_Informatics"},{"title":"List of fellows of the American College of Medical Informatics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_fellows_of_the_American_College_of_Medical_Informatics"},{"title":"American Association for Medical Systems and Informatics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Association_for_Medical_Systems_and_Informatics"},{"title":"Category:Health informatics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Health_informatics"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Medical Informatics:

## Definition

Medical informatics is the study and implementation of computer science to improve communication, understanding, and management of medical information.(no content)It is a discipline at the intersection of information science, computer science, and health care.

## Scope and Disciplines

Medical informatics is a spectrum of multidisciplinary fields that includes study of the design, development, and application of computational innovations to improve health care, combining healthcare fields with computing fields including computer engineering, software engineering, information engineering, bioinformatics, and data science.

## Key Applications

Medical informatics encompasses several specialized areas:

- **Clinical Decision Support**: AI programs are applied to practices such as diagnosis processes, treatment protocol development, drug development, personalized medicine, and patient monitoring, with a large part of industry focus in clinical decision support systems.

- **Telehealth**: Telehealth is the distribution of health-related services and information via electronic information and telecommunication technologies, allowing long-distance patient and clinician contact, care, advice, reminders, education, intervention, monitoring, and remote admissions.

## Professional Organizations

The American Medical Informatics Association (AMIA) is an American non-profit organization dedicated to the development and application of biomedical and health informatics in the support of patient care, teaching, research, and health care administration.

Web search results for query: "Artificial Intelligence"

Links: [{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial general intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence"},{"title":"Applications of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Timeline of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence in video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_video_games"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence visual art - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_art"},{"title":"Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence:_A_Modern_Approach"},{"title":"List of artificial intelligence films - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_artificial_intelligence_films"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence arms race - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_arms_race"},{"title":"Ethics of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_of_artificial_intelligence"}]

I've completed the web search for "Artificial Intelligence." Here's a summary of the key information found:

## Definition
Artificial intelligence is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.

## Core Goals and Techniques
The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.(no content)To reach these goals, AI researchers have adapted and integrated a wide range of techniques, including search and mathematical optimization, formal logic, artificial neural networks, and methods based on statistics, operations research, and economics.

## Historical Context
Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

## Recent Developments
Generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI, or GenAI) is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data.(no content)During the AI boom of the 2020s, text-to-image models such as Midjourney, DALL-E and Stable Diffusion became widely available to the public, allowing users to quickly generate imagery with little effort.

## Applications
Artificial intelligence has been used in applications throughout industry and academia. The search results show AI is being applied in areas ranging from healthcare and finance to military operations, astronomy, art, and entertainment.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

I've performed the web search for "Argumentation" and found comprehensive information. Here's what the results cover:

## Definition and Overview

Argumentation theory is the interdisciplinary study of how conclusions can be supported or undermined by premises through logical reasoning.(no content)With historical origins in logic, dialectic, and rhetoric, argumentation theory includes the arts and sciences of civil debate, dialogue, conversation, and persuasion.

## Key Components

An argument is one or more premisessentences, statements, or propositionsdirected towards arriving at a logical conclusion, with the purpose of giving reasons for one's thinking and understanding via justification, explanation, or persuasion.

## Scope of the Field

Argumentation includes various forms of dialogue such as deliberation and negotiation which are concerned with collaborative decision-making procedures, and encompasses eristic dialogue, the branch of social debate in which victory over an opponent is the primary goal, and didactic dialogue used for teaching.

## Practical Applications

Argumentation is a daily occurrence, such as in public debate, science, and law, including in courts by the judge, the parties and the prosecutor in presenting and testing the validity of evidence.

The search results also covered related topics like argumentation frameworks in artificial intelligence, argumentation schemes (templates for common argument types), and argument mining (automatic extraction of arguments from text).

Web search results for query: "Semantic Web"

Links: [{"title":"Semantic Web - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_Web"},{"title":"Semantic web service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_web_service"},{"title":"Social Semantic Web - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Semantic_Web"},{"title":"Semantic Web Rule Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_Web_Rule_Language"},{"title":"International Semantic Web Conference - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Semantic_Web_Conference"},{"title":"Metaclass (Semantic Web) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaclass_(Semantic_Web)"},{"title":"Extended Semantic Web Conference - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extended_Semantic_Web_Conference"},{"title":"Semantic Web (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_Web_(journal)"},{"title":"Talk:Semantic Web - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Semantic_Web"},{"title":"Journal of Web Semantics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Web_Semantics"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the Semantic Web:

## Overview

The Semantic Web, sometimes known as Web 3.0, is an extension of the World Wide Web through standards set by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C).(no content)The goal of the Semantic Web is to make Internet data machine-readable.

## Key Technologies

Technologies such as Resource Description Framework (RDF) and Web Ontology Language (OWL) are used to enable the encoding of semantics with the data.(no content)These embedded semantics offer significant advantages such as reasoning over data and operating with heterogeneous data sources.

## History and Vision

The term was coined by Tim Berners-Lee for a web of data (or data web) that can be processed by machinesthat is, one in which much of the meaning is machine-readable.(no content)He defines the Semantic Web as "a web of data that can be processed directly and indirectly by machines".

## How It Works

When applied in the context of the modern internet, it extends the network of hyperlinked human-readable web pages by inserting machine-readable metadata about pages and how they are related to each other.(no content)In this way, a machine can process knowledge itself, instead of text, using processes similar to human deductive reasoning and inference, thereby obtaining more meaningful results and helping computers to perform automated information gathering and research.

## Reception and Applications

While its critics have questioned its feasibility, proponents argue that applications in library and information science, industry, biology and human sciences research have already proven the validity of the original concept.

Web search results for query: "Explainable Artificial Intelligence XAI"

Links: [{"title":"Explainable artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explainable_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Xai - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xai"},{"title":"OpenAI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenAI"},{"title":"xAI (company) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XAI_(company)"},{"title":"Open-source artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-source_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial general intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence"},{"title":"Generative artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"AIXI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AIXI"},{"title":"Agentic AI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agentic_AI"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI):

## Definition

Explainable AI (XAI), generally overlapping with interpretable AI or explainable machine learning (XML), is a field of research that explores methods that provide humans with the ability of intellectual oversight over AI algorithms.

## Purpose and Goals

XAI aims to explain what has been done, what is being done, and what will be done next, and to unveil which information these actions are based on. This makes it possible to confirm existing knowledge, challenge existing knowledge, and generate new assumptions.

## Core Principles

XAI algorithms follow the three principles of transparency, interpretability, and explainability.(no content)White-box models provide results that are understandable to experts in the domain. Black-box models, on the other hand, are extremely hard to explain and may not be understood even by domain experts.

## Trust and Importance

As regulators, official bodies, and general users come to depend on AI-based dynamic systems, clearer accountability will be required for automated decision-making processes to ensure trust and transparency.

## Practical Techniques

SHAP enables to visualise the contribution of each feature to the output. LIME can locally approximate a model's outputs with a simpler, interpretable model.

## Historical Context

DARPA established the XAI ("Explainable Artificial Intelligence") program in 2014 to try to solve these problems.

## Web Search Results for "Robotics"

Here's a comprehensive overview of robotics based on the search results:

### Definition and Scope

Robotics is the interdisciplinary study and practice of the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.(no content)Within mechanical engineering, robotics is the design and construction of the physical structures of robots, while in computer science, robotics focuses on robotic automation algorithms.

### Key Components of Robot Systems

Robotics usually combines three aspects of design work: mechanical construction (a frame, form or shape designed to achieve a particular task), electrical components that power and control the machinery (used for movement through motors, sensing, and operation), and software (a program that determines when or how a robot does something).

### What is a Robot?

A robot is a machineespecially one programmable by a computercapable of carrying out a complex series of actions automatically, and can be guided by an external control device, or the control may be embedded within.

### Specialized Fields

The field includes several specialized subfields:

- **Soft Robotics**: Soft robotics is a subfield of robotics that concerns the design, control, and fabrication of robots composed of compliant materials, instead of rigid links.

- **Robotic Arms**: A robotic arm is a type of mechanical arm, usually programmable, with similar functions to a human arm.

### Industry and Applications

A robotics company produces or manufactures and sells robots for domestic or industrial use, and investment in robotics companies has grown due to increasing demand for automation.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper. Here's a summary of what was done:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** Survey

This paper is clearly a survey as indicated by its abstract which states it "reviews all the important methods and studies, as well as implementations that use Argumentation to provide Explainability in AI."

## Extracted Triples

I identified and documented **8 key entities** explicitly mentioned in the paper's title and abstract:

1. **Argumentation theory** (concept) - Core method for providing AI explainability
2. **Explainable artificial intelligence** (concept) - Primary field of the survey
3. **Machine learning** (method) - Combined with argumentation for interpretable models
4. **Artificial intelligence** (concept) - Foundational field being addressed
5. **Semantic Web** (tool) - Application domain for explainability
6. **Robotics** (concept) - Application field discussed
7. **Health informatics** (concept) - Medical application domain
8. **Law** (concept) - Legal application domain

## Validation Results

 **VALIDATION PASSED**
- Paper Type: survey
- Total Triples: 8
- Entity Types Distribution: 6 concepts, 1 method, 1 tool
- All Wikipedia URLs verified and valid
- All relation requirements met (all triples use "uses" relation, which is appropriate for a survey paper)

The triples_output.json file has been successfully updated with all the required information and has passed all validation checks.

- [Argumentation theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argumentation_theory)

- [Robotics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics)

- [Law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law)
